pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:4.1: 11. The training rule on being angry about a legal issue
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:5.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:5.2: At that time the nun Caṇḍakāḷī was angry that a legal issue had been decided against her, saying,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:5.3: “The nuns are acting out of desire, out of ill-will, out of confusion, and out of fear.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:6.1: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:6.3: “Just because she is angry that a legal issue has been decided against her, how can Venerable Caṇḍakāḷī say,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:6.4: ‘The nuns are acting out of desire, out of ill-will, out of confusion, and out of fear’?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:6.6: “Is it true, monks, that the nun Caṇḍakāḷī said this because she was angry?”

pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:6.15: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:7.1: ‘If a nun is angry because a legal issue has been decided against her, saying,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:7.2: then the nuns should correct her in this way:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:7.3: “Venerable, just because you are angry that a legal issue has been decided against you, don’t say,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:7.4: ‘The nuns are acting out of desire, out of ill-will, out of confusion, and out of fear.’
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:7.5: Perhaps it’s you who are acting out of desire, out of ill-will, out of confusion, and out of fear.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:7.6: If that nun still continues as before, the nuns should press her up to three times to make her stop.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11:7.7: If she then stops, all is well.
